Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Predicting mechanisms for the formation of terpenes - natural products from plants
Award.AbstractNarration:
Natural organisms produce thousands of organic molecules (natural products), but how and why specific molecules are produced remains unknown. Terpenes constitute a large class of complex natural products whose members have found applications in perfumery, medicine, food and wine flavoring, pesticides, among others. Understanding the chemical mechanisms by which terpenes are formed will allow for these structures to be produced in the laboratory on demand. This project will be conducted at Kyoto University, Japan with Dr. Keiji Morokuma, the developer of a new computational tool that will be used to connect molecular structure to natural product production. The limits of this new methodology will be tested on a naturally occurring terpene precursor, then it will be applied to mapping out the pathways for the formation of non-natural, designed terpene derivatives.

The global reaction route mapping (GRRM) strategy using the artificial force induced reaction (AFIR) method will be integrated with quantum chemical calculations on intermediates and transition state structures (TSSs) in terpene-forming pathways. Mechanistic studies on chemical reactions rely heavily on finding TSSs between two intermediates. The GRRM/AFIR method is an alternative approach to locating TSSs--often the most challenging aspect of a computational reaction mechanism investigation--opening the door to pathways that may be overlooked by humans. Of special interest is the effect of methylation on carbocation precursors to terpenes. Methylation of biologically relevant compounds has been shown to have profound effects on function and reactivity. The GRRM/AFIR method will allow the prediction of reactivity of substrates that are not yet known. Furthermore, GRRM/AFIR method for mapping chemical reactions and biosynthetic pathways will be applied to advance blind and visually impaired students' ability to search for TSSs independently and accessibly, as locating TSSs manually currently requires sighted assistance. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Terpenes, organic molecules formed by a variety of plants, animals, and insects (natural products), have both a variety of functions in vivo and a wide range of commercial applications including perfumery, food and beverage flavoring, medicines, and pesticides. It is important to understand the chemical mechanisms by which these natural products are formed for 1) comprehending our natural surroundings and biological systems and 2) using this knowledge to produce high quantities of natural products or related compounds in the laboratory on demand. A recent example of the success and positive impact of this approach is the industrial synthesis of the anti-malarial drug artemesinin, a terpene that was originally isolated from wormwood and is now produced on a scale that allows for mass use.

The mechanisms of terpene biosynthesis have been widely studied using two computational chemistry methods – manual transition state searching and molecular dynamics. Though these methods have been useful, Prof. Keiji Morokuma at the Fukui Institute for Fundamental Chemistry, Kyoto University, Japan, recently developed a more efficient method for chemical mechanism investigation. The global reaction route mapping (GRRM) strategy using the artificial force induced reaction (AFIR) method is an alternative approach for mapping reactions pathways. This new method seeks to survey the entire “landscape” of chemical reactions beyond where manual transition state searching and molecular dynamics may lead us. Previous collaborative work between Prof. Dean Tantillo (University of California, Davis Department of Chemistry) and the Morokuma group validated the GRRM/AFIR method by showing that it successfully located complex terpene-forming pathways found by the other two methods. More interestingly, they showed that this method found new paths that had not yet been considered. The discovery of these new pathways emphasizes the utility of this approach for the study of terpene biosynthesis mechanisms.

With the generous support from the NSF EAPSI program, I was able to visit the Morokuma group for 10 weeks to learn how to use this new computational chemistry software and extend its applications to a simple monoterpene system derived from geranyl pyrophosphate. (Terpenes are composed of 5-carbon chemical fragments called isoprene units, and terpenes composed of two isoprene units are known as monoterpenes, 10 carbons total.) This is the first time simple and complex potential energy surfaces for terpene-forming pathways have been studied using all three approaches. Through one-on-one mentoring, I learned how to implement the computational chemistry software with my investigation of monoterpene formation. I also gained experience with scripting (a form of computer programming) that allowed me to run multiple calculations in parallel, which increased my efficiency. The GRRM/AFIR method applied to the monoterpene system led to the discovery of new reaction pathways and product formation steps not yet revealed by the older methods. This mirrored the investigation of complex terpene-forming pathways described above.

Encouraged by these results, we applied the GRRM/AFIR method to study the effect of varying methylation patterns (a form of chemical alteration not uncommon in natural products) on chemically reactive precursors of terpenes. In some cases, methylation of biologically relevant compounds revealed new functionality and heightened reactivity. Using the GRRM/AFIR program, I found new, stable species of these chemically altered monoterpenes. The promising results that have come from studying terpenes via the GRRM/AFIR method will facilitate the study of other complex, natural product formation pathways.
